content: As usual we, like our politicians are attacking the problems azz backwards. Of course all should have a vote if they qualify. And the qualifications should not include wealth and taxes. The qualifications should include Apptitude and a knowlege of American history. Every one should pay tax and a flat percentage tax rate, eliminating write offs and the need for an IRS would solve that problem.If you make a dollar you owe a dime at ten percent. It all looks good on paper the way its set up in dollar values which shows the elite paying millions in taxes while the middle class only pay thousands and the poor pay hundreds or nothing. Convert that to percentage values and add the perks of write offs and tax free expense accounts and its clear to see the wealthy do not pay thier fair share. Its the burden of the middle class which is rapidly declining and our debt increasing.
reply: As usual we, like our politicians are attacking the problems azz backwards. Of course all should have a vote if they qualify. And the qualifications should not include wealth and taxes. content: The perception is that those who don't pay taxes are voting for individuals who will raise taxes on those who do pay taxes, so they can get more welfare benefits. This benefits nobody as we all know, because the tax increases are passed along to the public in the form of higher prices on goods and services and fewer jobs. "The World's Finest"

content: I personally feel that all citizens age 18 and older should be allowed to vote regardless of crimes committed, taxes owed, mental status, etc. But, your right to vote is not explicitly stated anywhere in the Constitution. There are places where it says that you cannot be denied a vote for particular reasons (age, race and gender), but nowhere does it state that everybody has a right to vote. ----http://www.usconstitution.net/constnot.html#vote
reply: I personally feel that all citizens age 18 and older should be allowed to vote regardless of crimes committed, taxes owed, mental status, etc. But, your right to vote is not explicitly stated anywhere in the Constitution. content: Instead of taking away the right to vote from those who don't pay, how about requiring something from every person who votes. If you can't pay taxes, community service, military service, or something. If every person is equal under our Constitution, you would think everyone could offer something, at least in gratitude, for the protection and freedom it provides. If every American citizen is worth something, maybe its time to show it by contributing something to our country in return.

content: Everyone who lives and breaths pays taxes of one sort or another. Even if you barter you are supposed to pay taxes on the value of the goods or services received. (Unless you make an unintended mistake.)

content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: Should you get a vote? The only real answer is, it depends. Should the poor schmucks in Iraq and the Stan get a vote? They don't pay taxes. Personally I feel that those on the dole should not be eligible to vote the entire time they are on the dole and for 6 months after. Those convicted of tax fraud are felons, and most states do not allow felons to vote. But until you are convicted you get to vote.

content: Who doesn't pay taxes? There are Federal, State, Local, Social Security, Medicare, Sales taxes, Property taxes. Even teenagers working at fast food restaurants pay taxes. Even undocumented (illegal) aliens pay some taxes.
